rComments: Doesn't answer emails. Doesn't care if you actually understand the material. Flaky and condescending.

As the previous review said, great lecturer. However, his perspective on teaching is disturbing. He specifically said that Riemannian geometry was NOT a prerequisite for this course: however, he told his TA to 'catch us up' on pseudo-Riemannian geometry during his two week 'absence', assuming a good grasp of Riemannian geometry. Truly shocked.

I really want to like this professor. His lectures are really good and he goes through most of the material very well. However, his nonchalant attitude when it comes to teaching, as well as his complete disregard for his students is shocking. He hasn't answered most emails since the start of class, and invents absences even when on campus.

He encourages class participation, which is understandable but if no one answers his questions he says stuff like  "you should know this" or "wow no one knows how to solve this?" or the statement that made me write this "If you don't know the integral, then i'll hang myself." If you don't mind this type of commentary, you'll be okay.
Spyros clearly cares a lot about his classes, but he's just no very good at it.

He is quite a good mathematician. Most of the time he follows the textbook a bit too much, obsessed with details in the book. But he sometimes provides very good insight into the material as well. His tests are hard, but not too hard, and are very educational. A very good prof overall.

Goes through the material too quickly. His notes are all over the place and his writing on the board gets so tiny and cramped it's difficult to see sometimes. Hates anyone talking and will point you out if you do. I found studying from the textbook way more helpful than attending his lectures.
